sols_html:
The stationary probability density, \(\bar{\mathbf{p}}\), satisfies the equation:

\[\begin{aligned} \bar{\mathbf{p}} = P\bar{\mathbf{p}}.\end{aligned}\]

We notice that \(\bar{\mathbf{p}}\) must be the eigenvector with corresponding eigenvalue \(\lambda = 1\). Thus, we need to solve for this eigenvector (making sure all the entries sum to 1 in order for it to be a probability distribution) using the equation \((P - I)\bar{\mathbf{p}} = \mathbf{0}\)

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} -3/4 & 1/4 & 1/4\\ 3/4 & -1/4 & 1/4\\ 0 & 0 & -1/2 \end{bmatrix}\bar{\mathbf{p}} = \mathbf{0} \quad \rightarrow \quad \bar{\mathbf{p}} = \begin{bmatrix}1/4 \\ 3/4 \\ 0\end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore, the stationary probabilities are probability 1/4 of being in state 1, probability 3/4 of being in state 2, and zero probability of being in state 3.

statement_html:
Consider a random walk that has transition matrix:

\[\begin{aligned} P=\begin{bmatrix} 1/4 & 1/4 & 1/4\\ 3/4 & 3/4 & 1/4\\ 0 & 0 & 1/2 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

Find the equilibrium probability vector (i.e. the vector at which probabilities remain unchanged from one step to the next).
